thread.title: Henrietta Lacks' family wants compensation for her cells - Baltimore Sun

author: Andrea K. Mcdaniels
title: Henrietta Lacks' family wants compensation for her cells - Baltimore Sun
text:
Henrietta Lacks' family wants compensation for her cells Henrietta Lacks 
Handout portrait of Henrietta Lacks who died in 1951 of ovarian cancer at Johns Hopkins. 
Handout portrait of Henrietta Lacks who died in 1951 of ovarian cancer at Johns Hopkins. (Handout) 
The walls of a City Hall conference room are adorned with portraits of several men from Baltimore's history: abolitionist Frederick Douglass, Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, former congressman and NAACP leader Kweisi Mfume and neurosurgeon Dr. Ben Carson, among others. 
On Thursday, they... 
The walls of a City Hall conference room are adorned with portraits of several men from Baltimore's history: abolitionist Frederick Douglass, Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, former congressman and NAACP leader Kweisi Mfume and neurosurgeon Dr. Ben Carson, among others. 
On Thursday, they... (Luke Broadwater) 
Johns Hopkins officials said in a statement that when the cells were taken there was no established practice for informing or obtaining consent from cell or tissue donors, nor were there any regulations on the use of cells in research. 
"Today, Johns Hopkins and other medical research centers maintain strict patient consent processes for tissue and cell donation," the statement said. "It is now standard practice to have an Institutional Review Board examine every research study involving human participants before it is allowed to begin." 
The medical institution said it hasn't profited from the cells.
